revision.text:
{{about|the concept of wellness as used by the alternative medicine community|the concept of wellness in scientific medicine|Health|other uses|Wellness (disambiguation)}}
[[File:Eight Dimensions of Wellness.png|alt=The Eight Dimensions of Wellness|thumb|The Eight Dimensions of Wellness]] '''Wellness''' is generally used to mean a state beyond absence of illness but rather aims to optimize [[Quality of life|well-being]].<ref name=NYT2010/>
The notions behind the term share the same roots as the [[alternative medicine]] movement, in 19th-century movements in the US and Europe that sought to optimize health and to consider the whole person, like [[New Thought]], [[Christian Science]], and [[Lebensreform]].<ref name=Kirkland>{{cite journal|last1=Kirkland|first1=Anna|title=What Is Wellness Now?|journal=Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law|date=1 October 2014|volume=39|issue=5|pages=957–970|doi=10.1215/03616878-2813647|url=http://jhppl.dukejournals.org/content/39/5/957|language=en|issn=0361-6878}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Blei|first1=Daniela|title=The False Promises of Wellness Culture|url=https://daily.jstor.org/the-false-promises-of-wellness-culture/|work=JSTOR Daily|date=4 January 2017}}</ref>
The term was partly inspired by the preamble to the [[World Health Organization]]’s 1948 constitution which said: “Health is a state of complete physical, mental and social well-being and not merely the absence of disease or infirmity.”<ref name=NYT2010>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/04/18/magazine/18FOB-onlanguage-t.html | work=The New York Times | title=Wellness | first=Ben | last=Zimmer | date=2010-04-16}}</ref> It was initially brought to use in the US by [[Halbert L. Dunn| Halbert L. Dunn, M.D.]] in the 1950s; Dunn was the chief of the [[National Center for Health Statistics|National Office of Vital Statistics]] and discussed “high-level wellness,” which he defined as “an integrated method of functioning, which is oriented toward maximizing the potential of which the individual is capable.”<ref name=NYT2010/> The term "wellness" was then adopted by [[John Travis (physician)|John Travis]] who opened a "Wellness Resource Center" in [[Mill Valley, California]] in the mid-1970s, which was seen by mainstream culture as part of the hedonistic culture of Northern California at that time and typical of the [[Me generation]].<ref name=NYT2010/> Travis marketed the center as alternative medicine, opposed to what he said was the disease-oriented approach of [[medicine]].<ref name=NYT2010/> The concept was further popularized by [[Robert Rodale]] through [[Prevention (magazine)|''Prevention'' magazine]], Bill Hetler, a doctor at [[University of Wisconsin–Stevens Point]], who set up an annual academic conference on wellness, and Tom Dickey, who established the Berkeley Wellness Letter in the 1980s.<ref name=NYT2010/> The term had become accepted as standard usage in the 1990s.<ref name=NYT2010/>
By the late 2000s the concept had become widely used in [[employee assistance program]]s in workplaces, and funding for development of such programs in small business was included in the [[Affordable Care Act]].<ref name=Kirkland/> The use of corporate wellness programs has been criticised as being discriminatory to [[people with disabilities]].<ref>Basas, Carrie Griffin, What's Bad About Wellness? (August 1, 2014). [[Journal of Health Politics, Policy and Law]], Vol. 39, No. 5, 2014. Available at [[SSRN]]: https://ssrn.com/abstract=2478902 </ref> At the same time, while there were magazines devoted to wellness, it was noted that mainstream news sources had begun to devote more page space to "health and wellness themes".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Kickbusch |first1=Ilona |authorlink1=Ilona Kickbusch |last2=Payne |first2=Lea |title=Twenty-first century health promotion: the public health revolution meets the wellness revolution |journal=[[Health Promotion International]] |date=1 December 2003 |volume=18 |issue=4 |pages=275–278 |doi=10.1093/heapro/dag418}}</ref>
The US [[Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration]] uses the concept of wellness in its programs, defining it as having eight aspects: emotional, environmental, financial, intellectual, occupational, physical, social, and spiritual.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.samhsa.gov/wellness-initiative/eight-dimensions-wellness|title=The Eight Dimensions of Wellness|last=|first=|date=2016|website=Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration (SAMHSA)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The wellness trend has been criticised as a form of [[conspicuous consumption]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Bearne |first1=Suzanne |title=Wellness: just expensive hype, or worth the cost? |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2018/sep/01/wellness-hype-superfoods-yoga-price |accessdate=7 September 2018 |work=the Guardian |date=1 September 2018 |language=en}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Complementary and alternative medicine]] *[[Healthism]] *[[Mindfulness]] *[[Organic food culture]] *[[Salutogenesis]] *[[Wellness tourism]] *[[Workplace wellness]]
== Reference == {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Wellness}} [[Category:Concepts in alternative medicine]] [[Category:Quality of life]]

[[File:Edith Wolfson Medical Center P1030041.JPG|thumb|250px|Wolfson Medical Center]] '''Wolfson Medical Center''' ({{lang-he|מרכז רפואי וולפסון}}) ([[transliteration]]: ''Merkaz Refui Wolfson'') is a [[hospital]] in [[Holon]], [[Israel]].Wolfson Hospital is located in southern [[Tel Aviv Metropolitan Area]], [[Tel Aviv District|Tel Aviv]] district of [[Israel]] in a vicinity abounded by a population of nearly half a million inhabitants. It ranks as the ninth largest hospital in Israel.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nrg.co.il/online/16/ART1/578/331.html|accessdate=2007-09-14|author=Ayala Hurwicz|date=2007-05-07|language=Hebrew|title=Sheba - Largest Hospital in Israel}}</ref>The medical center was founded with the assistance of the [[Wolfson Foundation]] and named after Lady Edith Specterman Wolfson, Sir [[Isaac Wolfson]]'s wife.<ref name="About">[http://www.wolfson.org.il/Index.asp?CategoryID=158&ArticleID=560 About The Edith Wolfson Medical Center]</ref>
== History == The medical center in Holon was opened to the public in 1980 on the southern [[Tel Aviv-Jaffa]] border. The center has grown since from 342 beds to over 650 beds in 2007 with an additional 30 outpatient beds.<ref name="About"/>
== Services == The Wolfson Medical Center departments are affiliated with the [[Sackler School of Medicine]], [[Tel Aviv University]] and tutors students during their [[Internship (medicine)|intern]] years. The center employs over 100 doctors that also hold posts, ranging from instructors to professors, at the university. The students come also from [[United States]], [[UK]], [[China]], [[Italy]], [[Ethiopia]], [[Ghana]], [[Ecuador]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Honduras]] and [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]].
